spans.content: Ab-initio molecular dynamics simulations of the reactivity of
Lucas M. Farigliano a, Patricia A. Paredes- Olivera b, Eduardo M. Patrito a,

a Departamento de Fisicoquimica, Instituto de Investigaciones en Fisico Quimica de Cordoba (INFIQC), Facultad de Ciencias Quimicas, Universidad Nacional de Cordoba, X5000HUA Cordoba, Argentina b Departamento de Quimica Teorica y Computacional, Instituto de Investigaciones en Fisico Quimica de Cordoba (INFIQC), Facultad de Ciencias Quimicas, Universidad Nacional de Cordoba, X5000HUA Cordoba, Argentina
- induced etching Molecular dynamics Density functional theory
We investigated the reactivity of fluorinated monolayer and bilayer
in relation to etching processes. We considered both the energetics and the dynamics of the different processes: a) interaction of fluorine species in the gas phase with
groups and c) the desorption of fluorine- containing molecules into the gas phase. The dissociative adsorption of
occurs at very low temperatures (100 K) and the surface becomes populated by
groups. Etching processes begin with the desorption of the
group and only at very high temperatures the desorption of
was observed. Sulfur vacancies left by the removal of S atoms are rapidly filled by F atoms due to the formation of strong
F bonds. The formation of a sulfur vacancy induces the subsequent formation of S- vacancies on adjacent surface sites, and this finally promotes the desorption of
species, thus leaving a surface pit defect. For a
bilayer with the top layer fluorinated on both sides, the etching of the top layer was observed as a consequence of the release of
The electronic properties of two- dimensional
depend on the number of layers.[1] Multilayered
. The direct bandgap of the monolayer confers

a strong luminescence and high quantum yield with promising applications in different optoelectronic devices.[2,3] Therefore, controlling the number of layers of 2D materials is indispensable for nanodevice applications because of their layer- dependent optical features. Controlling the thickness of
films during growth is a difficult task due to nonuniform domains having different number of layers.[4,5] A different strategy is to remove

layers after synthesis using post- treatment procedures. Etching is one of the key steps in materials processing in the semiconducting industry and several etching techniques have been proposed to control the layer number and patterning of 2D materials.[4- 12] The main etching techniques include plasma etching,[5,7,8,11,13] laser thinning,[4,14], and thermal annealing thinning.[6,15] Thinning of
leads to enhanced photoluminescence which is beneficial for photodetector fabrication. [13,16] Etching of
also induces the activation of the basal plane of
to enhance the hydrogen evolution reaction.[17,18].
[22]) used in gas- assisted etching are attractive candidates for the spontaneous etching of 2D materials because Mo and S elements form volatile compounds with fluorine at room temperature.
has been used to spontaneously etch
at room temperature with a uniform change of layer number.[22] Multilayer
can also be thinned down to monolayer and bilayer upon exposure to
etching was not observed after Cl- radical adsorption, and it required a subsequent
ion- beam desorption step to achieve the complete etching of one monolayer of
.[24] The atomic picture of etching mechanisms is unknown in most cases. For the
etchant, the following overall reaction has been proposed:[22]
, where the products are gaseous species.
The electronic structure of F adatoms on

has been studied using Density Functional Theory (DFT).[25- 27] At low coverages, the F atom adsorbs on top of the S atom whereas at high coverages the S- F bond is slightly tilted with respect to the surface normal.[25,26] The high electronegativity of fluorine induces a charge transfer of around 0.5 e
Fig. 1. Electron density difference plots after a) the adsorption of an
molecule on top of an S atom and b) the adsorption of an F atom on top of an S atom of
. Red lobules correspond to regions of charge accumulation
contour) whereas blue lobules correspond to charge depletion regions
towards the F atoms, which produces
.[25,26] Substitutional fluorine doping using a gentle
can be used to tune the catalytic activity of either the basal plane[27,28] or the edges[30] or
Notably, the surface chemistry involved in the interaction of fluorine atoms with the
surface has not been thoroughly investigated yet. Previous total energy calculations performed at the DFT level (corresponding to a temperature of
) only considered SF surface moieties, [25- 27] but failed to identify
moieties, which play a key role in the etching of
. In this work we first consider the energetics involved in a) the interaction of the
molecule and the F atom with the
groups and their surface reactions, c) the desorption of

species, which is the onset of the etching process. In the second part, we investigate the dynamics of the fluorinated surfaces at different temperatures, which clearly reveal the mechanisms of surface reactions and desorption processes. The
molecules and high surface coverages are readily obtained. The
surface group is the most stable, having stronger S- F bonds than the SF and
groups. The etching process mainly begins with the desorption of
species which, upon abstraction of an F atom from adjacent surface sites, leads to the desorption of
molecules into the gas phase. Sulfur vacancies are readily occupied by F atoms leading to the formation of strong Mo- F bonds and this finally leads to the desorption of

Ab- initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at the DFT level of theory were performed using the Quantum Espresso (QE) package.[31] The Perdew- Burke- Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange- correlation functional [32] and norm- conserving ultrasoft pseudopotentials were employed. [33] The one- electron wave functions were expanded in a plane- wave basis set up to a kinetic energy cutoff of 40 Ry (240 Ry for the density). The calculations were performed with a
which exposes 24 S atoms on each surface. For this large unit cell, calculations were performed at the

gamma point. A time step of 1 fs was used in the MD simulations and the temperature was set using a Berendsen thermostat. The longest simulations were performed up to around 25 picoseconds (25,000 simulation steps). Dispersive forces using Grimme's semiempirical DFT- D2 approach were employed in the dynamics involving the adsorption of
.[34] The climbing- image nudged- elastic- band (CI- NEB) method was employed to find energy profiles along reaction paths.[35] CI- NEB calculations were performed using a
supercell and the integration in the first Brillouin zone was performed with a
Monkhorst- Pack mesh.[36] Calculations were performed for both monolayer and bilayer
3.1. Energetics of formation of surface species from
The fluorine molecule adsorbs at a height of
above the sulfur atom with its axes parallel to the
surface (Fig. 1a). The adsorption process is exothermic with
, showing that there is a strong interaction between
monolayer. Small inorganic molecules have much lower adsorption energies, typically ranging from
.[37- 40] The F- F bond distance increases from
upon adsorption. The weakening of the F- F bond is a consequence of charge transfer process from the surface to the
antibonding orbital. The electron density difference plot in Fig. 1a shows a region of charge accumulation around the F atoms which resembles the shape of

orbital. Fig. 1b shows the electron difference plot around an F atom bound to a sulfur atom. Besides the region of charge accumulation around the F atom, regions of charge depletion are observed along the S- Mo bonds, which anticipate the weakening of these bonds. The formation of the S- F bond from a fluorine atom in vacuum has
and the adsorption of the F atom on an S vacancy site has
. In the latter case, the F atom adsorbs in the hollow site between three Mo atoms (see Fig. S1). The surface S- F bond
is weaker than the average S- F bond strength in the
molecule for which we calculated a value of
. The different strength between surface and gas- phase S- F bonds explains many features observed in the MD simulations. The strong interaction of F atoms on the pristine and S defective
surface and the weak F- F bond energy of the fluorine molecule, which is
[41], indicate that the dissociative adsorption of
will be an exothermic process, as we show next.

groups have the strongest S- F bond.
In order to obtain a deeper insight into the etching mechanism of multilayer

bilayer where the top layer is fluorinated on both sides as shown in Fig. 9a. We started the simulations with the top layer having a pit originating from 3 S to vacancies sites and 1 Mo vacancy, which is the outcome of the simulation shown in Fig. 8 (see the top view in the panel at 25.000 ps). We assume that the interlayer F atoms are incorporated at grain boundaries or surface pits. The snapshot in Fig. 9a (1500 K) shows that most F atoms are bound to the top layer, and this is more clearly evidenced in the trajectories of F and Mo atoms shown in Fig. 9b (for the sake of clarity, the trajectories of S atoms are not shown). On average, the trajectories of F atoms are closer to the top layer of Mo atoms than to the bottom layer (the red profile shows the trajectory of an F atom that penetrated the layer of S atoms). Fig. 9b shows that most F atoms diffuse freely in the interlayer region at

. Only the F atoms bound to the S atoms around the pit remain in this position, indicating a stronger SF bonding. Up to around 10 ps, the average interlayer spacing remains constant. Fig. S9 compares the interlayer separation in the absence of F atoms (around
) as well as when there are 5 and 12F atoms in the interlayer region (around

). However, in the latter case, the interlayer separation begins to increase after 10 ps of simulation time. This is explained by the snapshots shown in Fig. 9c. An SF group within the interlayer region around the pit reacts with a diffusing F atom (not shown) giving rise to an
group in the interlayer region (panel at 10.392 ps). As the simulation advances the
molecule abstracts F atoms to become

(panel at 13.479 ps) and the interlayer separation keeps increasing as is clearly shown in the panel at 15.567 ps of Fig. 9c. The decreasing energy profile in Fig. 9d indicates that these etching processes are exothermic. The black arrows in Fig. 9d indicate the times at which

desorbed from the top layer to the gas phase (not shown) whereas the red arrows indicate the desorption times within the interlayer region. In summary, this simulation shows the mechanisms involved in the etching of the top

also promoted the abstraction of adjacent F atoms when available to yield a gas- phase
molecule. As shown by Equation (13), this reaction is very exothermic with
. The sulfur vacancies left by the desorption of
species are rapidly filled by F atoms in adjacent SF groups. Equation (16) shows that this reaction is very exothermic

as discussed in section 3.1. The formation of a sulfur vacancy induces the etching of adjacent sulfur atoms, and this finally promotes the desorption of
species, thus leaving a surface pit defect (Fig. 8b, panel at 25.000 ps). For a
bilayer with the top layer fluorinated on both sides, the etching of the top layer was clearly observed as a consequence of the release of
In conclusion, our results help to unveil the main mechanistic steps involved in the etching of

and provide insights for experimentalists regarding the etching conditions. First, the energetics considerations show that the etching processes can be performed under mild experimental conditions comprising room or even lower
